paragraphs.name: 049a
paragraphs.text: I totally see it’s benefit to a project, especially with the increase in e-commerce and apps. Understanding what users like and dislike about your product is crucial, of course it is. However I just feel we are blurring the lines of what user experience is and what it needs to be. It feels like it has been put on a pedestal and personally a majority of the time I don’t see anything that is being done that is any different to what good designers do daily on every project.

As designers we can’t let this constant desire for a good user experience stifle the creativity and innovation that is needed in web design. We can still apply the principles of good user experience design to this, it just doesn’t need to impede as much as I worry it does. I have been guilty of it in the past, spending time on research, sitemaps and wireframes because I thought that is what you have to do. So much so that there is no time to do the best bit… create.
paragraphs.name: 41fd
3b11
paragraphs.text: I’m really beginning to dislike the term User Experience (UX) in relation to digital design, it’s overuse and mis-interpretation is not only alarming, but just plain annoying. Don’t get me wrong, it’s important and as the title of this post suggests, I am not against it. In fact I often use it to explain what I do or more importantly what my designs do, but that right there is my point. Good design is good user experience.

paragraphs.name: 32bd
paragraphs.text: I suppose this post is written out of frustration that more and more people are perceiving designers to be the ones who just paint pretty pictures. As if the decisions made when we craft a user interface are purely “what we thought looked nice.” If you’re a designer, developer or even a more trendy ‘website architect’ (who knows what they do!) and you aren’t designing with your users experience in mind, then I’d question what you are doing.

paragraphs.name: 77f7
paragraphs.text: Great read.

I’ve worked with people that see UX Design as precisely what you described, forgetting the design aspect. My adoration for the design element has seen me reduced to a UI designer in many instances with recruiters. You hit the nail on the head when you said it’s all User Experience.

paragraphs.name: c42f
paragraphs.text: Practically speaking, UX as it’s defined within a design function is more a call to design thinking than a independent discipline itself.
For instance when we design digital products such as websites and apps, we define and use UX as the method through which we design for the holistic product.

54b0a69f1a92.title: I didn’t get the point of this article.

paragraphs.text: I didn’t get the point of this article. Are you not sure whether you are a UX designer? Or you are not sure whether people around you understand what you do? It seems like you think of UX design as applicable only to the web. UX design and methodologies have a much broader application.

paragraphs.name: 105d
paragraphs.text: Great article and good point! What is also happening is that the frame designers work in is often foggy and hard to deal with (not defined scope, john doe users, small budget, narrow time frame…). And of course, everyday we read so much about “best UX practises bla bla” and “ideal projects” that then we feel over-responsible of doing it right. So, we apply things which already exist and work. We don’t dare.

Very much so. We have to be responsible for what we are creating and therefore push our designs as much as we can. Obviously at times things like budgets, clients and timescales will put restrictions on a project but that shouldn’t stop us putting the users first and creating the best experience we can.

paragraphs.name: d437
paragraphs.text: I must say I’m divided. I can understand your frustration but I also know that UX is (or supposed to be) focused on users. There is a bunch of times that we, as creators, have to step back in a certain product, idea or concept because users (or even the market) aren’t ready for it. This is really important but I can’t help to thing how user…

138204add875.title: Not trying to trivialise, but in my humble opinion, that’s what it boils down to: Have empathy for…

paragraphs.name: f1b0
paragraphs.text: Not trying to trivialise, but in my humble opinion, that’s what it boils down to: Have empathy for the people using, reading your stuff. Dont cling to your ego. Real empathy, for different people with different backgrounds. Sounds a bit esoteric. ;-) But to me personally.. great mindset to get started on anything that involves user interaction and architecture (and layout).

paragraphs.name: dd35
paragraphs.text: Really great write up. Thank you. I see this too. I can see that we are getting away from the true craft of UX. I’m curious what the impetus is? What is driving design teams away from solving problems through intuitive interaction design and now pushing to create experiences through visual design. We aren’t designing with affordances anymore.

paragraphs.name: a75a
paragraphs.text: So true.

paragraphs.name: b89b
paragraphs.text: Thanks Nate. You raise some very good points and it is something that has frustrated me of late. Like you said all design, regardless of medium, relies on many aspects about the user and therefore the experience it will give them. I think some people within digital design seem to have gotten carried away with this and at times almost act like it’s a new approach to design.
